title: Reading the Purim Scroll early
vignette: Small villages sometimes read the Purim scroll on the market day before the 14th. Should a town with enough residents do this too?

options.text: Read on the 14th like most places.
Read early for convenience of outlying farmers.

title: Women counting toward the quorum for prayer
vignette: A women's study group wants to read Purim scroll together with a words of praise or request. Can ten women form their own quorum?

options.text: Yes; women count for Purim scroll reading.
No; they should hear it with a men's quorum.

title: Working on Feast of Lots
vignette: Some say ordinary labor is discouraged on Feast of Lots morning. A shopkeeper wants to open briefly before the festivities.

options.text: Open the shop; work is permitted.
Keep it closed out of respect for the holiday.

title: Getting drunk on Feast of Lots
vignette: A lively group plans heavy drinking to fulfill the saying to "drink until one can't tell". Is this proper?

options.text: Moderate drinking only; avoid excess.
Drink freely to reach a joyful state.

title: Gifts to the poor vs. lavish feast
vignette: Money is limited. Should one prioritize giving more gifts of food gifts or hosting a large Feast of Lots meal?

options.text: Focus on gifts to the poor first.
Spend on the meal; joy is central.

title: Reading in translation
vignette: Some community members only understand the local language. May the Purim scroll be read aloud entirely in translation?

options.text: Yes; translation fulfils the obligation.
No; it must be in Hebrew.

title: Interrupting foundational document study for Purim Scroll
vignette: Scholars deep in learning hesitate to stop for the reading. Is hearing the Purim scroll more important?

options.text: Yes; everyone must pause to hear it.
They may continue studying instead.

title: Two days of Feast of Lots in walled cities
vignette: Residents of an ancient walled city keep Feast of Lots on the 15th. Travelers staying over Feast of Lots wonder whether to observe both days.

options.text: Observe both days to be safe.
Keep only the day of the place you're in.

title: Acting out the Purim Scroll drama
vignette: Youth plan a dramatic reenactment of the Feast of Lots story. Elders fear it trivializes the text.

options.text: Allow the play; it engages people.
Discourage it; keep the reading solemn.

title: Reading from a damaged text scroll
vignette: The community's Purim scroll has a few worn letters. A new one won't arrive in time. Can they read from the damaged text scroll?

options.text: Yes if most letters remain legible.
No; wait until a proper text scroll is available.

title: Interruptions during the reading
vignette: Children occasionally make noise during Purim scroll reading causing listeners to miss words.

options.text: Repeat the missed verses after quieting them.
Proceed without repetition.

title: Combining Purim scroll with other text scrolls
vignette: A printer wants to bind the Purim scroll together with other writings for convenience. Some say it diminishes its special status.

options.text: Bind it separately to honor it.
Combination is fine and saves money.

title: Standing vs. sitting for the reading
vignette: The reader prefers to sit due to fatigue. Others insist it must be read standing as a sign of respect.

options.text: Read standing despite discomfort.
Sitting is acceptable if needed.

title: Using a microphone
vignette: To accommodate a large hall, the reader suggests amplifying with a microphone. Some question whether electronic sound counts as hearing the Purim scroll.

options.text: Use the microphone so all can hear.
Avoid; each must hear the natural voice.

title: Reading again for latecomers
vignette: After finishing, a few people arrive who missed the Purim scroll entirely. Should the reader repeat it just for them?

options.text: Yes; reread so they fulfil the moral obligation.
No; they must find another reading elsewhere.
